name: 800XE
keyboard: Full-stroke keyboard, 57 keys, 5 function keys (Help, Start, Select, Option, Reset)ESC, TAB, CONTROL, SHIFT (x2), DELETE, BREAK, RETURN, CAPS, GRAPH MODE
rom: 24 kb (16 KB for OS, 8 KB for BASIC)
text: Five text modes, maximum : 40 columns x 24 lines
ports: Composite video output, Cardridge port, Expansion port, SIO peripheral port (tape, disk, printer, modem), 2 x joystick connectors
description:
The Atari 800XE was the last 8-bit machine produced by Atari. It was almost the same machine as the 800XL with a case almost the same as the 130XE. It was only sold in East European countries, mainly Germany and Poland.

The main hardawe difference with the 800XL was FREDDIE, a new memory management custom chip (also found in the 65XE) allowing to address up to 128 KB of RAM and to better share RAM area with ANTIC, the graphics chip.

The 800XE could be easily upgraded to 128 KB by adding two memory chips on board. The layout of the I/O connectors was exactly the same as the 130XE. Some games which were developed for the 130XE were compatible with the 800XE, but not backwards compatible with the 800XL.

The 800XE had a short life, it was sold for less than one year.


______________

Thanks to Erik Klooster for this picture

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPLETE SYSTEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>Atari 800XL with its power supply unit and the XL12 tape recorder.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GAMER SYSTEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>Complete system with its light gun, XC12 datarecorder (which doesn't need extra power supply), light pen and software cartridges <b>Bug Hunt</b> (for use with light gun), <b>Atarigraphics</b> drawing program (for use with light pen) and <b>Pole Position</b> (famous Formula One game). <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Edwin L. Westerhoff</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SIDES</strong></font><br><blockquote>One can spot the dual joystick connectors at the right side.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR CONNECTORS</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right:<br> • 13-pin serial connector where several peripherals can be connected in chain<br> • Cartridge connector<br> • Bus expansion connector<br> • RGB video output DIN socket<br> • RF/TV output jack<br> • Power in DIN socket and switch. Power is supplied by an external 5V AC adaptor</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> OPENED</strong></font><br><blockquote>The keyboard is put down onto a metallic shield which surrounds the mainboard and prevents from radio frequency interferences.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAINBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>The mainboard is pretty the same as the 130XE's, apart from the amount of RAM, 64 KB instead of 128 KB.<br><br> <b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> TV UHF modulator<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> 6502 CPU<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> GTIA (George's Television Interface Adapter), main video circuit<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> ANTIC chipset, manages the video buffer for the GTIA, memory access and CPU interrupts<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> 6520 PIA in charge, among other things, of the peripherals serial interface<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> Keyboard connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</font></b> POKEY, the sound chipset<br> <b><font color="blue">(8)</font></b> OS and BASIC ROMs<br> <b><font color="blue">(9)</font></b> FREDDY, the memory management and bank switching chipset<br> <b><font color="blue">(10)</font></b> 64 KB RAM. The baord can support a second bank of 64 KB.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSERT - RECTO</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.1000bit.net" target="_blank">www.1000bit.net</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dated december 1980</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (APR. 87) </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The Best''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert show the built-in user menu and system status.<br><br> The right located system is the dual-drive version.<br> The left one is the 10 MB hard-disk version.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DEC. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Christmas accounts" <br><br> "Casio, it counts"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JULY 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"access to the Forth power" <br><br> "with the Jupiter Ace, enjoy profesionnal experience of Forth"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1983 BADGES</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Thomson, the micro capital"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT#1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"I did click" <br><br> Cool french young boy, proud of its brand new Adam. Only the expansion module #3 version was available in France...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #2 (1983) </strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The columbia MPC is shipped with fully suported software that will save you $3,000. Included is the entire self-teaching Perfect Software family: Perfect Writer, a word processor; Perfect Speller, a 50,000 word dictionnary; Perfect Filer, a data base manager; and Perfect Calc, a financial calculation system.<br><br> In addition, you get MS-DOS, CP/M-86, Macro/86 assembler, BASICA, Asynchronous communication support, Diagnostics and the Columbia Tutor program...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE LOGO (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Apple Logo was a very successful implementation of Logo. It contained some advanced features such as property list and packages, as well as extremely good documentation.<br><br> At the time, Apple thought the Logo language would encourage schools to invest heavily in personal computers for all the class levels.<br> Sadly, Logo never became the revolutionary language that they had hoped for and very few schools taught it to their pupils (except in France).</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The memo from the company president:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Your purchase request for six personal computers just reached my desk.<br><br> What gives?<br><br> I thought you understood our grouth plans, Jack, but the computers you have recommanded are dead ends. They might do the job today, but what about tomorrow? They don't connect together to form any kind of functional system. The 8 bits aren't compatible with the 16 bits models. And I doubt the software that run on the computers you want will be of any use later when we're forced to buy computers that work together.<br><br> You saved us a little now, Jack, but your decision will cost us a bundle as we grow into the future. We are growing, Jack, and I'm sure that you want to be part of the growth.<br><br> See me before you go home tonight.<br> Tom<br><br></font> Cheer up Jack!<br><br> Now the advert:<br><br><font color="#666666"> If you don't want your boss to limit you growth, don't limit the growth of the company. Consider small business computers that can keep up with your business by giving you options for expansion in the future.<br> With Televideo Systems Inc. you get what no other small business computer can offer...</font><br><br> Perhaps jack was right...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DIABOLIK, FRENCH ADVERT. #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It will take your time, your body and your soul"...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><i>Texas Instruments home computer, simply unbeatable</i> <br><br> Notice that the man seems not to feel at ease with a computer keyboard and still doesn't use the right finger...<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Charles da Silva</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH FLYER</strong></font><br><blockquote>... featuring the Intellivoice</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> VC20 GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Christian Hart for this scan</p></blockquote>

item.description: Indus GT|||5''/14 disk-drive|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> INDUS GT</strong></font><br><strong>> 5''/14 disk-drive</strong><br><blockquote>The Indus GT Double Density Drive is considered by many the best floppy drive available for the 8-bit Atari's with its digital readouts and smoke plexi cover.</blockquote>

Astra 2001 FD unit|||Dual 5.25|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> ASTRA 2001 FD UNIT</strong></font><br><strong>> Dual 5.25</strong><br><blockquote>Dual 5.25" FDD unit using single side, single or double density floppy drives </blockquote>

Percom disc drive|||Advert|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PERCOM DISC DRIVE</strong></font><br><strong>> Advert</strong><br><blockquote>March 1983 Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The Percom Data AT-88 offers 88 Kbytes (formatted) in single-density, with plug-in ease of attachment to your Atari. The AT-88 has integral power supply, "no-patch" to Atari DOS and critical constant speed regulation.<br> Take advantage of this low introductory price of $488... </font> </blockquote>

Corvus Systems hard-drive|||10Mb hard-drive|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> CORVUS SYSTEMS HARD-DRIVE</strong></font><br><strong>> 10Mb hard-drive</strong><br><blockquote>This is a 10Mb hard-drive. With up to 8 multiplexers with 8 ports each it's possible to connect up to 64 Atari 800's up to a single 10 or even 20 megabyte Atari system. Still in use Today at the Fordham Prepatory School in the Bronx, NY is a 64 Atari 800 computer network hooked up to a single Corvus Hard drive system !  <br><br> The Corvus hard disk system also sported a unique and innovative back-up system called "The Corvus Mirror" which was a VCR interface system that allowed you to plug a standard Video Cassette Recorder (VCR) up to the Corvus Hard Drive System to save back-ups of the hard disk onto actual Video Tapes!!!</blockquote>

Touch Tablet||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> TOUCH TABLET</strong></font><br><blockquote>The touch tablet was the best tool for drawing and painting. It shipped with the AtariArtist cartridge.</blockquote>

emulator.name: The Atari 800 Emulator for the Mac
Atari++
emulator.description: Unix based emulator of the Atari eight bit computers, namely the Atari 400 and 800, the Atari 400XL, 800XL and 130XE, and the Atari 5200 game console

emulator.name: Atari800
emulator.description: Atari800 is an Atari 800, 800XL, 130XE and 5200 emulator for Unix, Amiga, MS-DOS, Atari TT/Falcon, SDL and WinCE
